meaning: Describes being in tune to someone else's feelings, thoughts and emotions to properly gauge and react to a situation

Collective feeling of sadness and oppression, defined by the Los Angeles Times as “intensely personal, yet carried around collectively, a national torch, a badge of suffering tempered by a sense of resiliency.”

Jeong is the country’s putatively real and unique form of social relational bonding. Sometimes translated as “harmony” or “coexistence,” its definition is far more complex. So much so that Koreans often have difficulty defining the word. Put simply, jeong refers to the emotional and psychological bonds that join the collective society of Korea; it pervades all levels, dissecting the world into various degrees of woo-ri (us) versus them.

The closest English term for 분위기 would be ambiance, but the term includes not just the vibe of a location but the feelings and emotions associated with the place and the people. While a place could have a great ambiance because of its decor, but bad 분위기 due to more intangible factors.
Have you ever described a bowl of hot stew as "refreshing"? In Korea, this is a natural concept in Korea's food culture.
This word literally translates to “without a reason.” In practice, it describes a situation that has no reason, or that is so absurd that it leaves you dumbfounded.
An exclamation indication joy and astonishment at the same time
The word itself derives from the word 'fighting', but has a completely different meaning. It is a term for encouragement.
Describes feeling "stuffy", used more to refer to emotions than physical condition
Feeling pity or disappointed by a situation or turn of events
Literally meaing "flower road", but refers to a path of life filled with happiness, as if you were walking on a path of flowers
Sudden downpour of rain that lasts about a minute
The sunlight that filters through trees
Taking a peaceful walk through the woods.
Tsun" means "pile up", and "doku" means "to read". Together, it refers to the act of buying so many books and ending up not reading them.
Appreciation of the beauty of imperfection and impermanence. It is both a traditional Japanese aesthetic as well as a style of art that focuses on restraint and simplicity.
